column5: My mom brought up something about grandkids and I said ‚ÄúI‚Äôm gonna be honest, we don‚Äôt want kids.‚Äù My mom is pretty chill so she was fine with that. I did the same thing with my dad but he took it differently.

My least favorite is ‚Äúyou‚Äôll love it because it‚Äôs yours‚Äù or ‚Äúit‚Äôs different when it‚Äôs your child.‚Äù Not only is that a slap in the face to adoptive families but I‚Äôm not going to love something I don‚Äôt want. I enjoy kids the same way that I enjoy dogs, as long as I can give them back to their people lol.

I went to a showing of Rocky Horror last year around Halloween and they had a costume contest. There was this one girl who had an amazing Eddie costume, and everyone just did a great job with their outfits. A young girl, maybe 10 years old, also joined the contest and won. I don‚Äôt know what she was dressed up as. I don‚Äôt know why you would bring your young child to a showing of Rocky Horror anyway, it was just kind of frustrating to me that these people put a lot of effort into their costumes and a kid won. I wasn‚Äôt mad at the little girl obviously, not her fault, just really confused as to why a parent would bring their child to an event with nudity, sex, and cursing. I dunno.

I did online classes like this for a year and a half! I dropped out of the program because I no longer wanted that career path, but a few things helped me:

-Make due dates for yourself if the school
doesn‚Äôt have them already. Put them in a calendar or planner of some kind. 

-Download the Forest app! It‚Äôs about $3, but so worth it. It basically locks your phone and if you exit the app when your timer is going, the tree dies.

-Create a small workspace. I have a tiny apartment and laid a blanket down on the floor and would work there on my laptop and I knew that was my work space!

I agree with you so hard. I think the sentiment is good but I also hate being called a survivor. It‚Äôs not strong, I had no choice but to survive. I‚Äôm a ‚Äúsurvivor‚Äù and I still get panic attacks if someone touches me or if I see my naked body for too long. I feel like there‚Äôs a stereotype that comes along with the survivor mindset that you have to be strong about everything. It‚Äôs exhausting to constantly be on my toes. Being a victim isn‚Äôt bad- being an abuser is.

I‚Äôve been a veterinary receptionist for over three years now, and I‚Äôm in school to become a vet tech, and work as an assistant sometimes, depending on the day. I also have an anxiety disorder.

When I first got my job I had never worked in the veterinary field either. I took home all the brochures we had, nexguard, heartguard, trupanion, anything and just became familiar with them. I googled medications we prescribed often so I became familiar with them. I didn‚Äôt start to feel truly comfortable with everything until about 6 months in. 

It does get better with time, and the job is a great learning experience if you want to do assistant or technician work in the future. Anxiety loves the familiar. If it becomes too much, I would look into a job in the kennel. That way you could still transition to an assistant but it isn‚Äôt as customer service based. 

Good luck!

Our guest list is about 55 people including plus ones. I‚Äôm inviting my immediate family and friends I consider family. If I‚Äôm friendly with them but we don‚Äôt talk or hang out regularly, I didn‚Äôt invite them. I didn‚Äôt invite family I don‚Äôt speak to either. For plus ones, I‚Äôm limiting them to married couples/people who live together, and the bridal party and groomsmen get plus ones also, but on the condition I know the person. I didn‚Äôt want people I haven‚Äôt ever met coming to my wedding lol. 

I didn‚Äôt invite any coworkers but invited my boss and his wife because I like them. I like my coworkers generally but don‚Äôt talk much with them outside of work. Hope that helps!

Is this the first anniversary? That one was the toughest for me. I‚Äôm sorry you‚Äôre going through this. My first anniversary I got wasted. This summer will be my 6th. Better things are coming ‚ù§Ô∏è

Ugh, anniversaries suck. I started using mine as a mini ‚Äúholiday‚Äù in which I celebrate myself. I‚Äôll buy myself dinner, watch something I love, or just do something entirely for me. My therapist suggested doing something positive around that time of year. It helps. Sending you love ‚ù§Ô∏è

After leaving my abusive ex I had a monumentally hard time getting changed and showering and anything that involved being naked, really. I would wear the same clothes for a couple days at a time just to avoid seeing myself naked. 

It gets better. I really like the way you worded this and know how you feel. Hugs if you want them ‚ù§Ô∏è

I understand that. For me, media that portrays the struggles of PTSD in an accurate way make me feel good as they can articulate things I may have a hard time with.
I felt that way for a brief period of time as a teenager until I realized NOT having kids was an option. For a while I was like ‚Äúmaybe I‚Äôll enjoy having one daughter‚Äù and stuff like that.

It‚Äôs been five years for me and I only just got my diagnosis. Healing takes time but it‚Äôs so worth it. 

If you like media about PTSD- check out ‚ÄúBarry‚Äù on HBO. It‚Äôs the absolute best depiction of PTSD I‚Äôve seen and I‚Äôve brought it up in therapy multiple times. 

I have similar trauma to you, and I‚Äôm so sorry that you‚Äôre going through this. It‚Äôs tough but you‚Äôll push through! Hang in there ‚ù§Ô∏è
Thanks! It‚Äôs better now :)

If you end up going, I would explain to the professor that you can get anxious (if you feel comfortable doing that) and may need some time to take a break. If not, don‚Äôt feel afraid to step away for a few minutes just to catch your breath. Try staying to the back of the class if you don‚Äôt have the option to wander a bit. I‚Äôm in a long term relationship with someone in recovery from something else and it hasn‚Äôt always been easy, but he‚Äôs been sober for a little over 4 years now. True recovery is possible, but it isn‚Äôt easy. 

Ask yourself if this is something you want to commit to. If you‚Äôre able, see a therapist and maybe check out a Nar-Anon meeting near you (you can look up meetings by zip code). Good luck.
